text: Good morning, today is Friday, June 23.

I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR News, 
and here are today's top stories:

The five people aboard a missing submersible 
in the North Atlantic Ocean are believed

dead. NPR's Jasmine Garsd reports they were 
descending to view the wreckage of the Titanic:

"According to the U.S. Coast Guard, 
debris from the Titan submersible was

found on the ocean floor about 1,600 
feet from the bow of the Titanic,

and that indicates a catastrophic implosion 
of the vessel. Rescue teams continue to map

the debris field but have indicated that it may be 
quite difficult to recover the bodies. For years,

there were widespread concerns about 
the safety of this vessel; among them,

its ability to withstand deep-sea ocean 
pressure. The ill-fated expedition was part of an

increasing and very lucrative form of high-risk 
adventure tourism, which remains unregulated.
"Jasmine Garsd, NPR News, New York."

President Biden will sign an executive 
order today aimed at improving

access to contraception and family planning 
services. As NPR's Tamara Keith reports, this

is timed to the first anniversary of the Supreme 
Court's decision overturning Roe versus Wade:

"This is Biden's third executive order related 
to reproductive health care since the Supreme

Court's Dobbs decision caused millions 
of Americans in conservative states to

lose access to abortion services. But 
this order doesn't address abortion,

and instead is focused on birth control. Jen 
Klein leads the White House Gender Policy Council:

'We're really trying to do three separate 
things, all related to each other, in this

executive order: The first is increase and expand 
options — contraceptive options — the second is

to lower out-of-pocket costs, and the third is to 
raise awareness about what options are available.

"The order calls for federal agencies to 
consider ways to make those things happen.
"Tamara Keith, NPR News."

India's prime minister, Narendra 
Modi, continues his high-profile

visit to Washington today. He'll 
have lunch at the State Department,

welcomed by Vice President Harris and Secretary 
of State Antony Blinken. Modi was the guest of

honor at a state dinner last night given 
by President Biden at the White House.

Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is in Paris 
holding talks about debt relief for developing

nations. She's also talking about the trade 
relationship between the U.S. and China.

Yellen says dialing back the relationship 
between both nations would not be wise:

"Trade and investment — open trade and investment 
— I think, is a win-win. Both sides gain. But

there are areas where we have concerns and, as 
I've made clear and others in the administration

have, as well, we will certainly take actions, 
for example, to protect our national security."
She spoke to NPR's "Morning Edition."

Forecasters say it's going to be extremely 
hot again today in Texas and in parts of

the southwest. Temperatures in southeastern 
Arizona could soar well into the triple digits.
You're listening to NPR.
